title: 114_hr4783
content: The Act titled "Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016" extends termination dates for SBIR and STTR programs from 2017 to 2022. Administrative funding deadlines are also extended to 2022. Required expenditure amounts are specified. The Small Business Act is amended to specify required expenditure amounts for SBIR program budgets from fiscal year 2018 to 2022 and each fiscal year thereafter. The Small Business Act is amended to set expenditure requirements for SBIR program budgets, with percentages increasing annually from fiscal year 2018 to 2022 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to set expenditure requirements for SBIR program budgets, with percentages increasing annually from fiscal year 2018 to 2022 and beyond, starting at 0.50 percent for 2018 and 2019, 0.55 percent for 2020 and 2021, and 0.60 percent for 2022 and beyond. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Annual reporting requirements under the Small Business Act have been amended to specify deadlines for submitting reports to Congress and the Administrator, with the deadline for submission set for December 31 and March 30 of each year, respectively. The Small Business Act now requires agencies to submit a simplified and standardized report to the Small Business Administration by March 30 of each year. The Small Business Act now mandates agencies to submit a simplified report to the Small Business Administration annually by March 30, with specific deadlines for various subsections. The Small Business Act requires agencies to submit an annual report to the Small Business Administration by specific deadlines for different subsections, such as March 30 for certain sections. The Small Business Act mandates that Federal agencies report how administrative funds were used each fiscal year by March 30 to the Administrator. Failure to submit the report will result in the agency not being eligible for funds unless the report is eventually submitted. The Small Business Act requires Federal agencies to report the use of administrative funds by March 30 each fiscal year. Failure to submit the report will make the agency ineligible for funds unless the report is eventually submitted. If an agency fails to submit the required report, certain conditions must be met for the agency to regain eligibility. SEC. 5. INDEXING AWARDS FOR INFLATION. Section 9 of the Small Business Act (15 U.S.C. 638) is amended to make various changes to subsections (j)(2), (p)(2)(B), and (gg)(3), including redesignating subparagraphs and clauses, and adding a new subsection at the end. The Small Business Act is amended to make changes to award amounts for Phase I and Phase II of SBIR or STTR programs, limiting Phase I awards to $150,000 and Phase II awards to $1,000,000, with adjustments for inflation. SEC. 6 amends the Small Business Act to change insertion incentives. SEC. 7 clarifies eligibility for certain small businesses. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility for certain small businesses under the SBIR and STTR programs. The Administrator is required to modify policy directives within 180 days of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Small Business Act is amended to clarify eligibility for certain small businesses under the STTR program. The Administrator must modify policy directives within 180 days of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. SEC. 8. COMMERCIALIZATION ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 9 of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program, requiring covered agencies to implement a program to award eligible entities with a second sequential SBIR award within one year of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program allows covered agencies to opt out if they have a similar program, limits agency funds to 5% for awards, and terminates on September 30, 2022. The Administrator must require a matching requirement for awards to eligible entities. The Commercialization Assistance Pilot Program will end on September 30, 2022. The Administrator must require a matching amount from a third-party investor for any award given to eligible entities. Funding from ineligible sources cannot be used to meet the matching requirement. An eligible entity cannot use funding from ineligible sources to meet the matching requirement for an award under the commercialization assistance pilot program. The size of the award is limited and will be distributed during the Phase II award period. To receive a second sequential SBIR award, the entity must submit an application to the covered agency. To apply for a second sequential SBIR award under a commercialization assistance pilot program, an eligible entity must submit an application with required information and matching funding details. The awarded funds can only be used for research and development activities that advance the entity's Phase II program towards commercialization. Recipients of awards are determined by the head of the covered agency. The commercialization assistance pilot program awards funds to eligible entities to advance their Phase II program towards commercialization. Recipients are selected based on the potential impact on research commercialization, technical feasibility, and improvements to the commercialization plan. The evaluation criteria for the commercialization assistance pilot program include assessing changes to the commercialization plan, progress in Phase II activities, third-party funding expectations, and the likelihood of commercial and societal benefits. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit an evaluation report within 3 years of the enactment of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit an evaluation report within 3 years of the Commercializing on Small Business Innovation Act of 2016 enactment. The report will include a summary of commercialization assistance pilot program activities, results achieved, and the number of small businesses receiving awards. The evaluation report will include details on the commercialization assistance pilot programs, such as the number of small businesses receiving awards, commercialization success rates, growth in employment and revenue, comparison with non-matching Phase II recipients, demographic information of participant companies, funds allocation at each agency, and third-party funding distribution. The evaluation report will include details on the geographic location of participant companies, funds usage at each agency, third-party funding sources, program effectiveness analysis, and recommendations for program improvement if made permanent. Definitions include 'covered agency' as a Federal agency with an SBIR program and 'eligible entity' as a small business receiving awards. The term 'covered agency' refers to a Federal agency with an SBIR program, while 'eligible entity' is a small business that has received Phase II awards. An 'eligible third-party investor' can be a small business, venture capital firm, individual investor, or non-SBIR government entity. 'Ineligible sources' include specific entities that do not qualify for funding. The term 'ineligible sources' refers to funding sources that do not qualify for SBIR funding, such as internal research funds, non-cash funding, funding from owners or affiliates, and debt-obtained funding. SEC. 9. INCREASED UNDERSERVED POPULATION PARTICIPATION WAIVER REMOVED. Federal agencies must use funds to carry out a policy directive and increase participation in States with historically low SBIR awards. Conforming amendment removes waiver authority under certain conditions.
